awd_titl_txt: WORKSHOP:  Summit on New Strategies for Measuring Assistive Technology Outcomes
awd_abstract_narration:
Today, over 56 million people in the United States report some degree of disability, a number which will likely grow in coming years as the so-called "baby boomer" generation ages.  Yet measuring the outcomes of interventions for persons with disabilities has challenged the disability and rehabilitation research community for decades.  Because of the extreme variability and unique circumstances of each individual, the gold standard of randomized control trials (RCT) becomes infeasible when trying to measure the true effects of using assistive technologies (AT).  This leaves the research community and those who rely on evidence of the efficacy of interventions (e.g., funding agencies and insurance companies) in a quandary.  This is funding to support a Summit (workshop) on New Strategies for Measuring Assistive Technology Outcomes, which will take place as part of and immediately following the 2016 annual RESNA conference to be held July 10-14 at the Hyatt Crystal City in Arlington, Virginia.  RESNA, the Rehabilitation Engineering and Assistive Technology Society of North America, is the one organization with an international focus that is devoted solely to technology for individuals with disabilities.  RESNA's membership consists of individuals and institutions covering a range of disciplines (including researchers, clinicians, suppliers, manufacturers, consumers and educators who work in both non-profit and for-profit settings), all of whom are dedicated to promoting the exchange of ideas and information for the advancement of assistive technology.  More information about RESNA and its annual conference is available online at http://www.resna.org.  The PI plans to leverage the fact that the upcoming RESNA conference will bring together national organizations and professionals with expertise related to assistive technology research and services, to organize a Summit on this critical topic at much less cost than would otherwise be required.  With this in mind, the conference organizers have woven an AT outcomes theme (consisting of a full day course, plenary and platform sessions, workshops, etc.) throughout the conference program, which will provide a backdrop and foundation for a full day of advanced discussions on ways to improve measurement of AT outcomes immediately following the end of the conference.  The consensus building and documentation of new methodologies resulting from the Summit will contribute key steps in transforming evidence based practice and its acceptance in new methodologies for outcomes data collection, analysis, and decision making.

The full-day invitational Summit at the end of the conference will aggregate current scientific thinking to lay the foundation for a transformative shift in rationale toward a new assessment methodology, to delineate steps that are required to create a new evidence based practice schema, and to begin sketching the key framework of variables required for such a new methodology.  Summit outcomes will include a report that will:

1) Summarize the state of the science of AT outcomes research.
2) Summarize the state of the science of AT outcomes research methodologies.
3) Delineate the current issues that restrain the current state of the science.
4) Generate actionable ideas for new AT outcomes research methods.
5) Articulate specific AT outcomes approaches for consideration by research and funding agencies.

It is anticipated that these future methodologies will require broad data collection from practitioners, consumers, and assistive technology distributors throughout their practices, and that these data from varied sources will need to be aggregated into a central database for inquiries and analysis.

por.por_cntn:
The paucity of outcomes data affects many stakeholders in the assistive technology (AT) field, including clinicians, researchers, manufacturers, and consumers. It is a substantial problem that adversely influences funding decisions for consumers, hampers clinicians who need to demonstrate the value of their service delivery programs, and makes it difficult for manufacturers to demonstrate the cost-effectiveness of their products. A national system of AT outcomes measurement could potentially mitigate these problems.

To address this issue and explore new approaches to the problem, RESNA conducted a set of AT Outcomes (ATO) activities at its June 2016 annual conference in Washington DC. This thread of activities on ATO content included a plenary talk on ATO, a 75-minute ATO Town Hall session, and a 1-day ATO Summit on July 15, 2016, immediately following the RESNA/NCART conference.  The summit brought together 33 subject matter experts from a variety of AT specialties and professional settings, including practitioners, researchers, research organizations,  policymakers, and manufacturers.

The overarching goal of the summit was to discuss the opportunities and challenges associated with creating a cloud-based AT outcomes system that would (a) allow upload of outcomes data by researchers, practitioners, and consumers; and (b) enable policymakers, third-party funders, consumers, practitioners, and researchers to look-up outcomes data for specific disability and/or device groups. The reportable outcomes would span the WHO ICF conceptual levels of quality of life, participation, activity, and body function and structures, as well as include key demographic fields and intervention descriptions that would allow “precision medicine” inquiries.

The 1-day ATO summit began with  a) a synopsis of the previous day Town Hall discussion, b) brief verbal remarks from representative stakeholder perspectives, and c) a summary of survey responses completed by participants prior to the summit. Following these introductory presentations, participants were grouped into six teams according to their primary role in AT. There were two teams for each main role of supplier, researcher, and practitioner. Participants self-selected their group.  Each team was given two directives: (a) identify and prioritize approximately 5 “grand challenges” that would confront creation of a cloud-based AT outcomes tracking system and data repository; and (b) identify actionable items associated with each grand challenge. Each team presented its consensus ideas to the larger group of summit participants, who then voted on the key ideas during a 30-minute balloting and informal discussion period.

Two doctoral-level researchers later conducted qualitative analysis of the grand challenges and actionable steps data to identify logical thematic groupings across the six teams.

The six teams generated a total of 34 grand challenges.  The three major categories were “Planning”, “Building the System”, and “Using the System”.  “Planning” was the largest category, with 22 grand challenges, addressing issues such as stakeholder buy-in and collaboration and identification of key outcome variables, measurement tools, intervention factors, and personal factors.  “Building the System” included 3 grand challenges that focused on obtaining the financial and human resources needed to implement the planned system.  “Using the System” included 9 grand challenges that related to the ease of entering data into the system and utility of data extracted from the system.

The teams generated 61 action steps, of which roughly two-thirds were unique. The largest number of actions related to defining the theoretical framework and measurement variables for an AT outcomes system.  The action steps included the need for a substantial effort to benchmark and analyze previous research and existing systems that may have relevance to an AT outcomes system.

The three themes of the grand challenges – “Planning”, “Building the System”, and “Using the System” -- suggest a temporal order of tasks for the actionable items. The collective emphasis on what to measure, ease of data entry, and utility of data extraction reflects participants’ pragmatism, concern for overall data quality, and empathy for those who would ultimately use such a system.

Planning actions had a strong mandate from participants as an essential starting point. A broad consensus will be needed from a diversity of players that spans professional roles (practitioners, vendors, manufacturers, researchers, consumers, facility administrators, policy makers, and reimbursement agencies), service delivery models, AT payment systems (VR, school-based, CMS, VA), AT device types, and consumer populations. The group acknowledged the highly likely difficulty in identifying a finite number of data fields that encompass key parameters, e.g., demographic factors of consumers, environmental factors for the consumer, AT services provided, AT device provided, outcome variables. Operationally, a cloud-based AT outcomes system must be practitioner-friendly and have the potential to yield meaningful conclusions from extracted data.
